verses.text: A great sign appeared in heaven: a woman clothed with the sun, with the moon under her feet, and on her head a crown of twelve stars.
verses.comment: The image of the woman has deep symbolic meaning. The twelve stars recall the twelve tribes of Israel and also point toward the later twelve apostles. Many traditional interpreters see spiritual significance in the woman's radiant glory, recalling Old Testament images (Gen. 37:9) and pointing to the destiny of God's people fulfilled in Christ's coming.

verses.text: She was pregnant and cried out in pain as she labored to give birth.
verses.comment: This verse connects to prophecies of Israel in labor (Isa. 66:7-8), ultimately pointing toward the birth of Christ. The woman's suffering hints at both physical and spiritual struggle.

verses.text: Then another sign appeared in heaven: behold, a great red dragon, having seven heads and ten horns, and on its heads seven crowns.
verses.comment: This dragon represents evil, traditionally interpreted as Satan. The seven heads, ten horns, and crowns signify enormous power and opposition, echoing Daniel’s visions of world empires opposing God (Dan. 7:7; Rev. 13:1).

verses.text: Its tail swept away a third of the stars of heaven and cast them down to the earth. The dragon stood before the woman who was about to give birth, so that when she gave birth it might devour her child.
verses.comment: The fallen stars often symbolize angels who followed the adversary in rebellion (Isa. 14:12). The desire to destroy the woman's child reflects the enemy’s ongoing war against the promised Messiah from Genesis onward.

verses.text: She gave birth to a male child, one who is destined to rule all the nations with an iron rod. Her child was snatched up to God and to His throne.
verses.comment: This child is Christ, the Messiah foretold to rule with justice (Ps. 2:7-9). His being taken up points to His Ascension, emphasizing His divine authority and protection. The reference to ruling nations connects prophecy and fulfillment.

verses.text: The woman fled into the wilderness, where she has a place prepared by God, so that she might be nourished there for one thousand two hundred sixty days.
verses.comment: Wilderness themes recall times of trial and protection (like Elijah in 1 Kings 19:3-8). The set period corresponds to other prophetic times in Revelation, symbolizing God’s faithful care amid persecution.

verses.text: Now war broke out in heaven: Michael and his angels fought against the dragon. The dragon and his angels fought back,
verses.comment: Michael, known as a chief spiritual warrior (Dan. 10:13; Jude 9), engages in cosmic conflict. This reflects both a literal battle and a spiritual reality in which heavenly forces oppose evil.

verses.text: but they did not prevail, and there was no longer any place for them in heaven.
verses.comment: The defeat of the dragon signals the decisive victory of God. Evil and its followers are expelled from the holy presence.

verses.text: So the great dragon was thrown down, that ancient serpent called the devil and Satan, who leads the whole world astray. He was thrown down to the earth, and his angels were thrown down with him.
verses.comment: Here, the text explicitly connects the dragon to the serpent of Eden (Gen. 3:1-4), revealing the continued deception and spiritual warfare present since the beginning of human history.

verses.text: Then I heard a loud voice in heaven saying, 'Now salvation and power and the kingdom of our God, and the authority of His Christ have come, because the accuser of our brothers has been cast down, the one who accuses them day and night before our God.'
verses.comment: The triumph of Christ is declared through this heavenly chorus. His authority brings the promised kingdom. The accuser’s defeat means believers now find their final vindication in the heavenly court.

verses.text: They overcame him by the blood of the Lamb and by the word of their testimony. They did not love their lives so much that they were afraid to die.
verses.comment: Victory comes through Christ’s sacrificial death ('blood of the Lamb') and faithful witness. The willingness to suffer and even die for the truth ties to the call for saints to persevere.

verses.text: Therefore, rejoice, O heavens and you who dwell in them! But woe to the earth and the sea, for the devil has come down to you in great fury, because he knows his time is short.
verses.comment: Heaven celebrates the victory, but the warning underscores the intensification of spiritual conflict on earth before the final consummation. The urgency reflects both present trials and future hope.

verses.text: And when the dragon saw that he had been cast down to the earth, he pursued the woman who had given birth to the male child.
verses.comment: The hostility toward the woman recalls the ancient enmity between the serpent and the woman’s offspring (Gen. 3:15). This points to a recurrent theme of spiritual attack against the people of God throughout salvation history.

verses.text: But the woman was given two wings of a great eagle so that she could fly from the serpent into the wilderness, to her place, where she is nourished for a time, times, and half a time, away from the serpent.
verses.comment: The eagle’s wings represent supernatural aid, seen also in Israel’s deliverance (Ex. 19:4). The symbolic time period matches prophetic language in Daniel (Dan. 7:25), signaling God’s sovereignty over history and protective care.

verses.text: And the serpent poured water like a river out of his mouth after the woman, to sweep her away with a flood.
verses.comment: Flood imagery often stands for overwhelming threats. Yet, as throughout Scripture, God reliably intervenes to safeguard His chosen people, preserving His promises.

verses.text: But the earth helped the woman and opened its mouth to swallow the river that the dragon had poured out from his mouth.
verses.comment: God uses creation itself to thwart evil’s plans, a motif seen with Moses, Elijah, and the Psalms. Divine providence is visibly at work.

verses.text: Then the dragon was enraged at the woman and went off to make war with the rest of her offspring, those who keep God’s commandments and hold fast to the testimony of Jesus.
verses.comment: The 'rest of her offspring' represents all faithful believers continuously opposed by evil. Keeping God's commandments and witnessing to Jesus highlights both faith and obedience, integral to the apostolic tradition in the universal Church.
